definition:
A [*beprisque number*]{} $n$ is an integer which is either one more than
a prime number and one less than a perfect square, or one more than a
square and one less than a prime. That is, either
$(n - 1) \in \mathbb{P}$ and $\sqrt{n + 1} \in \mathbb{Z}$ or
$\sqrt{n - 1} \in \mathbb{Z}$ and $(n + 1) \in \mathbb{P}$.

The beprisque numbers below a thousand are 1, 2, 3, 8, 10, 24, 48, 80,
82, 168, 224, 226, 360, 440, 442, 728, 840. The listing on the OEIS,
A163492, goes further but omits 1. It could be argued that a beprisque
number should itself not be a square, but then it becomes difficult to
justify why beprisque numbers that are themselves primes are allowed.

The only prime beprisque numbers are 2 and 3. For a prime number to be a
beprisque number, it has to neighbor another prime number; the only two
primes fitting that bill are of course 2 and 3.

The only odd beprisque numbers are 1 and 3. For an odd number to be a
beprisque number, it has to neighbor an even prime, and since 2 is the
only even prime, only 1 and 3 can be beprisque numbers.
